results.title: Kip and David. Episode 11.
results.creator_credit: Corinne Cantrill, Arthur Cantrill and Firebird Films
results.brief_description:
Episode number 11 of Series “Kip and David”.
Kip and David visit the plantation area of a bush sanctuary where they see koalas in the trees. David befriends the kangaroos. They observe emus sitting on their nests and inspecting the eggs. Some of the emu chicks have already hatched so Kip and David follow one of the emus with its brood of seven chicks as they move through the trees in the sanctuary. Music by Nancy Tow. Narrated by Roy Dunlop.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Corinne Cantrill, Arthur Cantrill and Firebird Films

results.title: Kip and David. Episode 01
results.creator_credit: Corinne Cantrill, Arthur Cantrill and Firebird Films
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “Kip and David”.
David, a young boy, goes by boat to Stradbroke Island on a holiday. As he collects Banksia cones in the bush, he hears honey-eaters followed by piping music played by a friendly elf. Together they explore the caves along the coast. Music by Nancy Tow. Narrated by Roy Dunlop.

results.title: Kip and David. Episode 10.
results.creator_credit: Corinne Cantrill, Arthur Cantrill and Firebird Films
results.brief_description:
Episode number 10 of Series “Kip and David”.
It is a rainy day and Kip and David play indoors. They decide to try potato printing and create some curtains. After the rain, they put the curtains up in Kip’s house. Music by Nancy Tow. Narrated by Roy Dunlop.

results.title: Kip and David
results.creator_credit: Arthur Cantrill, Corinne Cantrill and Firebird Films
results.brief_description: A thirteen part children’s adventure series made by Arthur and Corinne Cantrill about a young boy called David who meets a bushland elf while holidaying on Queensland’s Stradbroke Island and embarks on a series of adventures that highlight Australia’s wildlife and natural surroundings.

results.title: Keating on Impressionists
results.creator_credit: Richard Fawkes, Richard Beighton, Channel 4 Television Corporation and Moving Picture Company
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Keating on Painters Series”.
Tom Keating, art forger explains the importance of “plein air” painting to the Impressionists and paints pictures in the style of Rousseau, Boudin and Pisarro. While recreating the a Rousseau he talks about the palette of the painters, the techniques of painting trees and skies, and the different sense of values when painting outdoors or in a studio. He paints a “seaside” painting of Boudin using an initial wash and then making a simple figurative statement.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Richard Fawkes, Richard Beighton, Channel 4 Television Corporation and Moving Picture Company

results.title: Keating on Restoration
results.creator_credit: Richard Beighton, Richard Fawkes, Channel 4 Television Corporation and Moving Picture Company
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Keating on Painters Series”.
Tom Keating, an English artist and television personality, demonstrates the art of restoring an old painting. He collects a century old “pot boiler” from his local pub and explains in detail the restoration process.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Richard Beighton, Richard Fawkes, Channel 4 Television Corporation and Moving Picture Company

results.title: Kinemacolor
results.brief_description: Kinemacolor was the most successful process for colouring early cinema. Invented in 1906 by film pioneer George Albert Smith, it achieved the illusion of colour by capturing and projecting black-and-white film through alternating red and green filters.
results.description: Kinemacolor was the most successful process for colouring early cinema. Invented in 1906 by film pioneer George Albert Smith, it achieved the illusion of colour by capturing and projecting black-and-white film through alternating red and green filters. The first Kinemacolor motion picture ever filmed was A Visit to the Seaside (1908), and the first public screenings were held in London a year later. During the height of its popularity, more than 260 films were made with Kinemacolor and exhibited across Europe and the United States in over 250 venues.
description_for_label: Kinemacolor was the most successful process for colouring early cinema. Invented in 1906 by film pioneer George Albert Smith, it achieved the illusion of colour by capturing and projecting black-and-white film through alternating red and green filters. The first Kinemacolor motion picture ever filmed was A Visit to the Seaside (1908), and the first public screenings were held in London a year later. During the height of its popularity, more than 260 films were made with Kinemacolor and exhibited across Europe and the United States in over 250 venues.
